headline: STUDENTS AT TUFTS HOLD OWN EXERCISES
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass., May 31 (AP)—The 1,500 Tufts Univer sity students who boycotted the official university com mencement yesterday attended their own ceremonies today. The rites departed radically from traditional exercises.

headline: Samuelson Scores War
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, May 31 (AP)—Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of the Mas sachusetts Institute of Tech nology tonight called “that war in Indochina” the “single great est specter hanging over the economy.” The “greatest single blessing that could affect the pocketbook of the American public would be for us to get right out of Southeast Asia and cut our losses,” the economist said in a local television broad cast.

headline: Nixon Chat With Demonstrators Contained a Lesson, Aide Says
lead_paragraph: NEW CONCORD, Ohio, May 31 (UPI) — President Nixon made small talk about football and surfing to put college pro testers at ease in a confronta tion at the Lincoln Memorial May 9, but he really wanted to help them to understand the “lessons of history,” Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press sec retary, said today.

headline: Paul Harvey, ‘Voice of the Silent Majority,’ Opposes Nixon's Cambodia Move
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO—The postman, as he usually does, rang for the third time the other day at Paul Harvey's trim, native‐stone house in the exclusive Chicago suburb of River Forest. He was bringing the day's third large bag of mail—most of it letters from applauding listeners of the man who is called, and on occasion calls himself, the “voice of the silent majority.”
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: Buddhist Faction Begins a Hunger Strike in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31—Several hundred Buddhist monks and nuns of the militant An Quang faction began a 48‐ hour hunger strike today.

headline: Beards, Peace Symbols and Daisies at Vassar's Commencement
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 31 — Peace symbols crowned a sea of mortar boards and a Pomeranian scampered among the audi ence with a red protest band tied to his rear left leg. But Vassar graduated its seniors today (as did Smith and Mount Holyoke) in the well bred, tranquil style that has always been expected of the elite women's colleges.
author: By Marylin Bender Special to The New York Times

headline: ENEMY UNITS QUIT VIETNAM RESORT, AVOIDING A FIGHT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31—About 75 Vietcong and North Vietnamese soldiers, who seized part of the resort city of Dalat yesterday, slipped past hundreds of encircling Govern ment troops today and escaped into the surrounding hills.

headline: Man Is Shot in Brooklyn During 2‐Car Gun Battle
lead_paragraph: One man was wounded and three suspects were being held by the police after a running gun battle yesterday afternoon between the occupants of two cars in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

headline: Sweden's Premier Prepares for 9‐Day U.S. Visit
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, May 30 — Premier Olof Palme of Sweden will begin a nine‐day visit to the United States on Wednes day, and he sees his trip as an opportunity to explain “the ideas and interests this small country stands for.”
author: By John M. Lee Special to The New York Times

headline: Democratic ‘Bosses’: Mechanics of Power
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn Democratic lead er telephoned his Congressman last month and set in motion the events that brought Pvt. Joseph C. Caruso halfway around the world, from a line company in Vietnam to his ail ing mother in Red Hook.
author: By Martin Tolchin

headline: Students Defend U. of Virginia Head
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 31—On the afternoon of May 6, a Wednesday, Dr. Edgar F. Shannon Jr., president of the University of Virginia, was pelted with mashmallows and that night students threatened to break into his home.

headline: Haack Terms War No. 1 Stock Factor
lead_paragraph: Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Ex change, said yesterday: “The Vietnam war is the single most important factor as far as the stock market is concerned.”

headline: Surtax Extension Sacked
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) — Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wis consin, said today he was Introducing legislation to con tinue the 5 per cent surtax on corporations until the end of the war in Southeast Asia. Mr. Reuss said extension of the surcharge, now scheduled to expire July I, would bring in $2‐billion a year—enough to offset deficits projected by the Administration.

headline: Nixon ‘Encouraged’ by Briefing on War
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 31—President Nixon received briefing from his leading ad visers and commanders today on the operations in Cambodia and the war in Vietnam and was reportedly “encouraged” by what he heard.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Lawyer Becomes the 4th Candidate to Oppose Dodd
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, June 1—Donald J. Irwin, a Norwalk lawyer who served three terms in the House of Representatives, to day became the fifth candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from Connecticut.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: 8 More Newsmen Vanish in Cambodia; Total Missing at 24
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 1—Eight more newsmen were reported missing in Cambodia today and were believed cap tured by North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops.
author: By Sydney H. Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Asks Saigon's Aid
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 — State Department officials said today that South Vietnamese military authorities had been asked to assist in the search for the missing newsmen.

headline: U.S. Hints Saigon Won't Get Air Aid In Cambodia Drive
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 1—The White House hinted to day that the United States might not provide tactical air support to South Vietnamese forces in Cambodia after June 30, the deadline for the with drawal of American troops from Cambodia.

headline: HOUSE COMMITTEE CUTS 8555‐MILLION FROM FOREIGN AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1—The House Appropriations Commit tee, citing domestic budgetary problems, voted today for a $555‐million cut in the Adminis tration's foreign aid program.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Judge Bars Flying Flag at Half‐Staff As a ‘Political’ Act
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS, June 1—A State Supreme Court justice Chas ruled that the American flag may not be flown at half staff to express “an idea which in its origins and in its totally involves an expression of a political concept.”

headline: On Med‐Evac Copter, Faces and Pain
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, May 29 — Twenty‐year‐old Conrad Graff, a warrant offi cer who is the pilot of a medical ‐ evacuation helicop ter that carries the wounded in South Vietnam and Cam bodia, keeps looking at his passengers.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: 9 PUT ON PROBATION IN S.D.S. MOB CASE
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) — Nine members of the Students for a Democratic Society pleaded guilty today to charges of aggravated battery and mob action stemming from a demon stration last September protest ing the start of the Conspiracy 7 trial.

headline: Nixon Aide Forecasts an Upturn
lead_paragraph: Federal Budget Director Robert P. Mayo came to Wall Street yesterday to reassure the investment community that the Nixon Administration was con fident of a business upturn in the second half of 1970.
author: By Terry Robards

headline: NIXON ANSWERS BOY, BROTHER OF A HERO
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) — President Nixon has reas sured a 10‐year‐old Maryland boy that the youth's brother, soldier killed in Vietnam, is in heaven.

headline: Fair Access to TV
lead_paragraph: The President of the United States can rightly call upon the television networks whenever he wishes to speak about the Vietnam war or any other major mat ter. Tomorrow evening he will make an interim report on the Cambodian operation; another one is promised at the end of the month when all American troops are scheduled to have returned to South Vietnam.

headline: TRUSTEE OF N.Y.U. QUITS IN PROTEST
lead_paragraph: An 18‐year trustee of New York University submitted his resignation yesterday to pro test what he described as the university's “political activist role” in connection with recent protests against United States military involvement in South east Asia.
author: By Leonard Buder

headline: MRS. ROMNEY URGES U.S. PULLOUT BY '71
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 1—Lenore Romney, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate from Michigan and wife of George Romney. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called today for the withdraw al of all American troops from Vietnam next year.

headline: Quarry's Future Hinges on Foster Bout
lead_paragraph: Mac Foster served two tours of combat duty in Vietnam with the Marines. In one of 14 battles, the 27‐year‐old ser geant knocked out a 50‐caliber machine gun with a grenade. He has been recommended for the Silver Star, as a result of that action near Chu Lai.
author: By Deane McGowen

headline: G.O.P. CHIEF VIEWS CAMBODIA AS BOON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1—The Republican National Chairman, Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, said today that United States involvement in the Viet nam war no longer served the national interest, and he pre dicted that the Cambodian foray would help make it pos sibe to “get the hell out of there.”
author: By William Robbins Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu Is Reported Acting to Block Move By Ky to Exploit His Role in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1—President Nguyen Van Thieu was reliably reported today to be moving swiftly to block Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky from making political capital out of his active role in South Vietnamese military operations in Cambodia.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Troops Find Big Hospital in Enemy Base Complex in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 (AP) — United States troops found today an under ground hospital in a North Viet namese base complex in Cam bodia that already had yielded tons of enemy munitions and supplies.

headline: Hatfield Absolved by Senate of Franking Misuse
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) — Members of the Senate — Republicans and Democrats, hawks and doves—ralied today around Senator Mark O. Hat field, Republican of Oregon, in a rare display of unity.

headline: Doubts an Ambush
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) — Accounts of peasants in the area where group of television reporters disappeared Sunday raised a question today whether the men had been ambushed.

headline: Rochester Peace Drive Spreads Across Nation
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N. Y.—When the four students were killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University on May 4, nearly 1,000 of the University of Rochester's 3,300 undergraduates met in a dining hall to seek a way to vent their anger and frus tration.
author: By William E. Farrell Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON AIDE BACKS 'INCOMES POLICY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—A high Treasury official told Congress today that in his per sonal opinion the time had come to “give serious consideration” to some form of voluntary restraint on wages and prices.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: House War Foes Plan Attack On Debt Ceiling Increase Bill
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) —Antiwar Representatives said today they would try to amend a proposed debt ceiling increase in order to cure United States involvement in Southeast Asia.

headline: U.S. Completes an Inquiry Into G.I.‐Looting Charges
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam (AP), June 2—The United States command has completed an in vestigation into charges of looting lodged against American troops who captured the Cam bodian town of Snoul last month. Any disciplinary action that may be taken will be car ried out by the units involved, a spokesman said today

headline: TV RATE CUT ASKED FOR POLITICAL ADS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 — The Federal Communications Commission challenged Con gress today to broaden its drives for cut‐rate political ad vertising on television and for modification of the “equal time” rule that now frustrates campaign debates.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I.'s Still Go to the War, And Many Are Skeptical
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif., June 2 —Above the coffee shop in the shiny new Oakland In ternational Airport is a row of 24 clocks telling the time at 24 points around the globe, including the Azores, Dakar and Bombay.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld Special to The New York Times

headline: THAI VOLUNTEERS TO GET U.S. ARMS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2— The State Department said to day that the United States would provide arms and equip ment to ethnic Cambodians liv ing in Thailand who go to Cam bodia for military duty.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Changes Urged
lead_paragraph: Howard J. Samuels outlined yesterday a program for party political reform that he said he would work for if elected Governor.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: A ‘Crisis’ Seen
lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 21 —Arthur J. Goldberg began a three‐day upstate campaign to day in his quest for the Demo cratic nomination for Governor by chiding Governor Rockefel ler for “unsound and unfair budget practices” and by pledging to consolidate or abol ish state agencies grown “fat” with patronage.

headline: Washington: The Student Invasion
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—The capital is full of university students these days, lobbying the Congress for peace in Southeast Asia. Potentially, they are a powerful new politi cal force in the nation—there are 7 million college students and half the population of the country is under age 25—but they are inexperienced and disorganized and sorely in need of leadership.
author: By James Reston

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: June 2. 1970

headline: Unruh, Murphy, Tunney Capture California Races
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 2 — Assemblyman Jess Unruh was nominated by California Democrats tonight to run against Gov. Ronald Reagan, who was unopposed for the Re publican nomination.
author: By Wallace Turner Special to The New York Times

headline: Five Plead Guilty in a Plot To Ransack Dow Complex
lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Mich., June 2 (AP)—Five members of a group calling itself “Beaver 55” en tered pleas of guilty today to charges of conspiracy to will fully and maliciously damage property of the Dow Chemical Company.

headline: U.S. Vietnam Policy: An Assessment
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 — There is widespread doubt among the most experi enced American observers in South Vietnam that current United States policies will bring lasting peace. Although 110,000 American troops, have been withdrawn from Viet nam and enormous strides have been made in pacification in the last 18 months, the United States still faces vast problems in extricating itself.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Columbia Head Assails War, but Hundreds Walk Out
lead_paragraph: President Andrew W. Cordier of Columbia University evoked applause from an outdoor com mencement audience of 8,000 persons on the campus yester day when he declared that the Indochina war's 44.000 Ameri can dead, 300,000 wounded and $100‐billion cost “cannot be justified” either by its char acter or “any conceivable re sult.”
author: By Peter Kihss

headline: South Vietnamese Losses Heavy at Post
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) —North Vietna mese sappers overran part of a Government fire base in the far northern part of South Vietnam today but were beat en back after inflicting heavy casualties on the South Viet namese defenders.

headline: Democratic Senate Candidates Stressing Foreign Policy Issues
lead_paragraph: Foreign policy issues occu pied the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Sen ator from New York yester day.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: Military Officers Join Drive Against the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2, (AP)—The antiwar move ment has reached the United States military officers corps.

headline: Foreign Affairs: The Arrogance of Ignorance— II
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW—President Nixon correctly estimated the advance military and diplomatic impli cations of his decision to order U. S. troops into Cambodia to clean out Vietnamese Commu nist sanctuaries and, as dis cussed in a previous column, enormous booty was seized while Russia and China dis played prudence in their initial reactions. However, where Nix on made a grievous miscalcula tion was in judging repercus sions at home.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Transcript of President's Address on Situation in Indochina
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address to the nation last night on the war in Indo china, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: AGNEW SALUTES WEST POINT CLASS
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 3 — Vice President Agnew praised the leadership qualities of graduates of the United States Military Academy today while attacking what he termed “criminal misfits” and “charla tans of peace” who cause na tional confusion.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Mood of the Electorate
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 3 —If President Nixon's handling of the economy, student unrest and Indochina has moved the electorate to the left, as some politicians believe it has, you couldn't prove it by the results of yesterday's primary elec tions. It was not a good day for liberals or for doves. InAlabama, George C. Wallace showed that race is still the dominant fac tor in his state's politics, 105 years after the last Union soldier fired the last shot. But the ef ficacy of appeals to racial fears is not what it once was, even in Alabama. Only 51 of every 100 Alabamans who voted “stood up for George,” and most of the well‐educated whites and nearly all the blacks were among those who sat down.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Old Grads' June Reveries Fall Victim to Turmoil on Campuses
lead_paragraph: In this soft time of the year, when members of the city's university clubs are wont to loll in their leather armchairs savoring sweet summer memories of long gone commencements and class days, many are finding this June that—even in their thoughts—they can not go home again.
author: By Michael Stern

headline: 32 NIXON HECKLERS HELD IN TENNESSEE
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 3 — Forty‐seven warrants have been issued in connection with, the heckling of President Nixon at a rally by the Rev. Billy Graham in the University of Tennessee Stadium last Thurs day night.

headline: NIXON DESCRIBES CAMBODIAN DRIVE AS GREAT SUCCESS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 — President Nixon said tonight that the allied drive into Cam bodia was “the most successful operation of this long and dif ficult war” and that he was now able to resume his with drawal of American troops from South Vietnam.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: A Fighting General
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3—At least a dozen times in the last month when his troops were stalled on Cambodian battlefields, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri has swooped down to them in his helicopter, strode to the front of their ranks and assumed temporary com‐ mand to get them moving. Once, in his impatience, he scrambled atop an armored car and, jabbing his swagger stick toward Viet cong sniper positions in a Cambodian farmhouse, shout ed an order to charge, giving it all the authority he could muster in his compact 5‐foot 4‐inch, 140‐pound frame.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Williams Campaigns
lead_paragraph: United States Senator Harri son A. Williams Jr., who won a decisive victory in Tuesday's Democratic Senate primary election in New Jersey, showed every indication yesterday of unifying badly split Democrats in the state for the first time since 1965.
author: By Ronald Sullivan

headline: ‘Keep Your Cool,’ Dow Advises Targets of Antiwar Protesters
lead_paragraph: The Dow Chemical Company does not make napalm any more, but the company has had so much experience in deal, ing with the uproar it caused that Carl A. Gerstacker, Dow's chairman, came up with an in dustry primer yesterday on how other companies might handle similar confrontations.
author: By Robert J. Cole

headline: Saigon Force Relieves Mountain Post
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (AP)—A fresh South Vietnamese force reached a mountain outpost in the north west corner of the country today and relieved a garrison hard hit by two days of heavy fighting. Field reports said enemy pressure on the post was easing.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SENDS GROUP ON WAR TOUR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) —A special White House mis sion left today on an inspec tion tour of Vietnam and Cam bodia. The group was heavily weighted with Governors and Congressmen who support President Nixon's policy in In dochina but included one dis senting Senator, Thomas J. McIntyre.

headline: Unruh and Reagan Trade Charges After Gaining California Governor Nominations
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3— Ronald Reagan and Jess Unruh were attacking each other to day even before the votes were all counted in the primary elec tions that made them rivals in November for the governorship of California.
author: By Wallace Turner Special to The New York Times

headline: Foes of Cambodia War Win Senate Test, 54‐36
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3—In a key test of strength on the Indochina‐war issue, a biparti san coalition in the Senate demonstrated today that the coalition commands a clear majority supporting legislative restrictions on future military activities in Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Sorensen Attacks 3 Rivals for the Senate
lead_paragraph: For the first time, one of the candidates in the campaign for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York at tacked the other three yester day.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: 43 NOBEL LAUREATES BID NIXON QUIT WAR
lead_paragraph: Forty‐three American win ners of Nobel prizes in science have subscribed to a letter calling on President Nixon to “rise to the heroism that these times demand” through a swift end to United States participa tion in the war in Southeast Asia.

headline: 2 Ex‐Navy Ships Here Turned Over to Saigon
lead_paragraph: Two crews of South Viet namese sailors took com mand here yesterday of two former United States Navy ships in a transfer ceremony described by an American admiral as an example of Vietnamization of the war in Southeast Asia.

headline: Dissidents Confront Rockefeller After Speech to Museum Group
lead_paragraph: An address to the American Association of Museums con vention yesterday brought Gov ernor Rockefeller a standing ovation — and a confrontation afterwards by a group of dis sident artists.
author: By Grace Glueck

headline: PEACE CORPS GROUP PETITIONS FOR PEACE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 — Protests within the Peace Corps against the expanded fighting in Southeast Asia have been brought home to Joseph H. Blatchford, the director, in antiwar petitions signed by a few hundred members on two continents.

headline: A.C.L.U. COMES OUT AGAINST THE WAR
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union has adopted a resolution to work for the “immediate termination” of the war in Southeast Asia in what was termed a “major departure” from the organization's tradi tional role as a defender of in dividual rights.
author: By Barbara Campbell

headline: Rockefeller Praises Revenue Sharing
lead_paragraph: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 3—Governor Rockefeller called the revenue‐sharing plan passed by the 1970 Legislature the “single greatest fiscal advance” in the history of rela tions between the state and local government.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: President Argues Time Is on His Side
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3—The unprecedented “success” that President Nixon proclaimed to night for the American military venture into Cambodia is not subject to statistical proof or challenge. For his calculations dealt essentially not with what has happened but with what will result in the future: fewer casualties for American troops, more training time for South Vietnam ese troops and firmer understand ing of Mr. Nixon's resolve in the mind of the enemy.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Hearing on Guard Delayed
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 3 (UPI) — A hearing was post poned today until June 11 in a suit by the American Civil Lib erties Union charging Adjutant General S. T. Del Corso of Ohio with using state funds to coerce National Guardsmen into sup‐ porting the Indochina war. The suit also said that General Del Corso, commander of the Ohio National Guard, used state per sonnel to get the guardsmen to line up behind President Nixon and his policy in Vietnam.

headline: TV: Reaction to Nixon Speech Varies
lead_paragraph: Regular Commentators and Guests Divided the reaction of television commentators and invited studio guests to President Nixon's speech Wednesday evening on the Indochina war ranged from succinct skepti cism, sharp criticism and a degree of support to a broad conclusion that not much news had come from the White House.
author: By Jack Gould

headline: Vietnamese Reds, in Paris, Denounce Nixon's Address
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 4—The Viet namese Communist delegates, speaking at today's session of the Vietnam peace talks, de nounced President Nixon's address last night on Cambo dia and expressed satisfaction at the opposition in the United States to his Asian policies.

headline: G.I.'s at Tayninh Just ‘Kids’ and ‘Crazy’ to a 41‐Year‐Old Maid
lead_paragraph: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, May 30—Nguyen Thi Khao is 41 years old and the American soldiers that she works for are the age of her oldest children.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Letter About Army Costs a Recruiter His Air Force Post
lead_paragraph: MERIDEN, Conn., June 4 (AP)—An Air Force recruiting sergeant who described the Air Force as “virtually noncombat ant” and called Army draftees cannon fodder has been re lieved of his duties here.

headline: Ky Gets Royal Welcome in Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 4—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam, wel comed like a visiting potentate, arrived today for a conference with the new Cambodian lead ers to resolve the delicate ques tion of Saigon's military role in this embattled country.
author: By Sydney H. Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: Good Time to Be Alive, Nixon Tells Scholars
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) —President Nixon today told a group of 119 high school seniors, chosen by a commis sion as 1970 Presidential Scholars, that despite “fears turmoil and uncertainty,” this was a fortunate time to be alive.

headline: 114 Letters Mailed To GI., Now Dead, Never Reached Hirn
lead_paragraph: VERMILION, Ohio, June 4 (UPI)—An investigation began today after parents of a Viet nam war casualty learned that 114 letters mailed to their son in a military hospital were never delivered.

headline: 11 PROFESSORS BID AGNEW CURB TONE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Eleven University of Minnesota professors told Vice President Agnew today that his public rhetoric was “driving moderates into the arms of extremists.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Swedish Leader, in U.S., Avows Amity
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4— Europe's youngest Premier, the intellectual and leftist Olof Palme of Sweden, today began a nine‐day visit aimed at per suading Americans that his country's opposition to the war in Vietnam did not mean it was hostile to the United States.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Exhibit to Stir Opinion on P.O.W.'s Open in Capitol
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 — A life‐sized, chillingly realistic looking exhibit, designed to arouse public opinion in behalf of the release of American pris oners of war by the North Viet namese, was installed at the Capitol today with the backing of House Speaker John W. McCormack.

headline: Washington: The President's Report on Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4— President Nixon made Cam bodia sound so good on the TV the other night that it almost seems a pity to leave the place. “All our military objectives have been achieved,” he said, and the whole adventure was “the most successful operation of this long and difficult war.”
author: By James Reston

headline: Antiwar Amendment Group Opens 5th Avenue Office
lead_paragraph: A committee seeking an amendment to the New York City Charter to provide a legal test of the constitutionality of the war in Indochina opened a campaign headquarters yester day at 650 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street.

headline: MAYOR LOSING POST AFTER RAID ON DALAT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (Reuters)—The Mayor of Dalat, the Central Highlands resort city that was infiltrated by Vietcong guerrillas last weekend, will be replaced, the official South Vietnamese press agency reported today.

headline: FOE SEIZES POST NEAR PNOMPENH, THEN IS REPULSED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 — Communist troops seized a village called Sethbo today and then lost it to a Cam bodian counterattack in a bat tle only 10 miles southeast of Pnompenh, officers in the field reported. It was the closest major fighting to the Cam bodian capital so far.

headline: G.I.‐Pullout Plans Await End of Drive in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird disclosed tonight that President Nixon's senior military advisers would meet at a site in the Pacific forwhat he called a “major re deployment conference” short ly after the last American troops are withdrawn from Cambodia on June 30.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: SHOOTING REPORT IS BEING STUDIED
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, June 4—Federal, state and local authorities are investigating reports that Buf falo policemen fired shotgun pellets, wounding students on the campus of the State Univer sity here, during a disturbance last month.

headline: SENATE UNIT DENIED PEACE GROUP'S DATA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) —The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co lumbia temporarily blocked a Senate subcommittee today from subpoenaing records of an antiwar organization that oper ates coffeehouses and publishes underground newspapers near military bases.

headline: Du Pont President Scores Asian War
lead_paragraph: For the second time in two days, a major corporate execu tive has hit out against the country's involvement in Viet nam and its effect on the econ omy.
author: By Gerd Wilcke

headline: 13 U.S. AIDES ARRIVE FOR INDOCHINA STUDY,
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP)—A 13‐man fact finding party of members of Congress and officials arrived today. One of them said they intended to “look at the bunk ers” uncovered by allied forces inside Cambodia.

headline: Problem of Vietnamese Minority Tops Ky's Agenda in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5—The potentially explo sive issue of how to resolve the fate of the Vietnamese minority of 400.000 in Cambo dia is the most difficult prob lem on the agenda of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's current visit to Pnompenh.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: L.I. Students Vote to Reject Commencement Speaker
lead_paragraph: OCEANSIDE, L. L, June 5 (AP)—Graduating students at Oceanside High School voted today against having any speaker at commencement ex ercises, following a controversy over their choice of an anti Vietnam war Congressman.

headline: Sorensen Voices Doubt On Help of State Party
lead_paragraph: Theodore C. Sorensen, they Democratic State Committee's designated candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that he was not sure that or ganization support would help him in the June 23 primary.
author: By Richard Reeves

headline: Artists to Withdraw Work at Biennale

headline: Ambro Decries Racism in Campaign
lead_paragraph: Jerome A. Ambro, a white man running against a Negro for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, said yesterday that it was “very dif ficult” for him to campaign be cause everything he says is in terpreted as racism or bigotry.

headline: Optimism in Washington By WILLIAM BEECHER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10— Senior military planners here, surprised and elated by the per formance of South Vietnamese military units in Cambodia, say that it may bring about a shift in the strategy for conducting the war once most American soldiers leave Vietnam.

headline: Thieu Sets Tie to Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP) — President Ngu yen Van thieu signed a decree today establishing a permanent South Vietnamese Embassy in the Cambodian capital, Pnom penh, the Government radio re ported.

headline: U.S. Ambassador Cheered On Visit to Swedish City
lead_paragraph: SUNDSVALL, Sweden, June 10 (UPI)—Several hundred per sons cheered and applauded Ambassador Jerome Holland to day at the end of a four‐day Visit to this industrial city in northeastern Sweden.

headline: Kosygin Says Talks In China Are Stalled
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 10—Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin reported to day that the seven months of talks with Chinese Communist officials in Peking had failed to make any appreciable prog ress.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Army Center Graduates New‐Style Advisers for Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N. C., June 9—The newly reorganized John F. Kennedy Center for Military Assistance has just graduated its first class of new “ugly Americans”—39 officers who received a concerted six‐week smattering of knowledge in the Political and social sciences.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Chotiner, Long a Nixon Aide, Cautious on G.O.P. Prospects
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10— Murray Chotiner emerged from seclusion as a White House ad viser for an hour this morning to provide some new insights into President Nixon, the un folding Republican campaign and, just incidentally, himself.

headline: Unions for Goldberg Say Others Will Come Over
lead_paragraph: A group of union leaders promised strong support yes terday to Arthur J. Goldberg and hinted that other unions, now committed to Governor Rockefeller, might “soon have a change of heart.”
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: Laotians Reported Joining Foe in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 10—The Government here re ported today that Laotians had joined the North Vietnamese and Vietcong military forcesi forces that were fighting in the Siemreap area in northwest Cambodia.
author: By Sydney H. Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: Both New York Senators Condemn Ouster of Allen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10—Dr. James E. Allen Jr. of New York, who openly broke with the Nixon Administration over the Cambodian invasion, was oust ed today as the Government's too education official.
author: By Richard D. Lyons Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON UNIT BACKS DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10—On the eve of a crucial Senate vote on the Nixon Administration's Indochina policy, the White House received from a Presi dential commission an optimis tic report on the push into Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: BUDDHIST MONK, 74, IS SUICIDE IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday. June 11 (AP)—A 74‐ year‐old Buddhist monk burned himself to death in Saigon early today to protest against alleged Government persecution and to appeal for peace in Vietnam.

headline: Washington: For the Record
lead_paragraph: THE PRESIDENT

headline: WORDS OF NIXON CHANGED BY AIDES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 10—The official transcript of President Nixon's latest news conference quotes Mr. Nixon as having as serted that United States forces in Cambodia had captured “rockets by the thousands and small arms ammunition by the millions.”
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: THANT SAYS BIG TWO HOLD KEY IN MIDEAST
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.. June 11 —Secretary General Thant said today that only agreement between “the two biggest pow ers”—the United States and the Soviet Union— could end the rising level of war going on in the Middle East.

headline: 70 CIVILIANS DEAD IN A VIETCONG RAID
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 — Vietcong guerrillas shot their way through a South Vietnamese hamlet early today, killing 70 civilians in their homes, a United States military spokesman said.

headline: Advertising: Hopeful Look at Society's Ills
lead_paragraph: The World Congress of Advertising ended yesterday on the subject of society's ills—its dominant theme for four days.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: SAIGON WILL RELEASE 62 DISABLED P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 11—The Saigon Government announced today that it would release next month 62 disabled war prison ers and 24 fishermen captured at sea off North Vietnam. A spokesman for Hanoi indicated that his Government would raise no obstacle to the transfer.

headline: SOVIET WIDENS AID TO NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 11—The So viet Union announced today that it was increasing its mili tary and economic aid to North Vietnam as a result of intensi fied fighting in Indochina.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Cambodian Evaluation

headline: AGNEW BIDS PARTY CITE NIXON RECORD
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Vice President Agnew appealed to Republican Congressional candidates tonight to campaign on the record of President Nixon.

headline: ABUSE OF POWER CALLED A DANGER
lead_paragraph: Arthur J. Goldberg, calling for sweeping legislative reform, accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of a “cynical” abuse of executive power that he said had robbed the Legislature of its independence and creativ ity.
author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: EX‐OFFICER TELLS OF SONGMY DATA
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11—A former Army intelligence officer has written in a magazine arti cle that the American Army unit involved in the alleged Songmy massacre received conflicting intelligence information.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: The Senate Reasserts Itself
lead_paragraph: The Senate took a reassuring step toward re asserting its constitutional checks over the war making powers of the President yesterday in rejecting an effort to transform the Cooper‐Church amendment into a virtual blank check for future military opera tions in Cambodia.

headline: Angkor the Masterpiece Of a Vanished Empire
lead_paragraph: Angkor, now in the hands of North Vietnamese forces, is generally regarded as the consummate masterpiece of the vanished Khmer Empire, which flourished from the 9th to the 13th century.

headline: Dr. Allen Says Partisan Restraints Interfered With His Duties
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Dr. James E. Allen Jr., who was forced to resign yester day as the Government's chief education official, declared to day that the partisan con straints placed on him by the Nixon Administration had made it impossible for him to administer the Federal educa tion bureaucracy properly.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Swedish Leader Senses ‘Kind of Division’ in U.S.
lead_paragraph: Premier Olaf Palme of Sweden said last night that he sensed “a kind of division in this na tion and an emotionally charged atmosphere” very unlike what he knew as a college boy in Ohio or when he had visited 36 states “by the hitchhiking method.”
author: By McCandlish Phillips

headline: 3 Arrested in War Protest
lead_paragraph: Two young men and a teen age boy described by the police as demonstrators protesting the war in Vietnam were arrested yesterday after entering the draft board at 201 Varick Street and reading the names of war dead from a list they had carried with them. The three were identified as William J. Dorfer Jr., 26 years old, of 430 Columbus Avenue, a clerk; Wil liam J. McGuire, 23, of Hilltop Road, Port Washington, L. I., a tutor, and Stephen Kurzyna, 16, of 2885 Briggs Avenue, the Bronx, a student.

headline: Allied Drive Into Cambodia Causing New Protests in South Vietnam, With Students Playing a Major Role
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11—The allied intervention in Cambodia has resulted in a new wave of protests by South Viet namese against the Saigon Government.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: War Protested in Australia
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, June 11 —Five women chained them selves to the railings of the public gallery in the House of Representatives in Canberra today in protest against Aus tralia's conscription and in volvement in the Vietnam war. Policemen cut the five women free. The House Speaker, Sir William Aston, ordered that the women not be charged.

headline: White House Plans Conference of, by and for Youth
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. June 11— A national conference intended to be of young people, by young people and for young people was announced today by the White House.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON IS REBUFFED BY SENATE, 52‐47, ON CAMBODIA ISSUE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 11— In a rebuff to President Nixon, the Senate refused today to modify proposed legislative re strictions on future American military operations in Cam bodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Indochina Debate in Senate Shifts to Mercenaries Issue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 12— The Senate's debate on Indo china shifted today to the issue of whether the Administration should be permitted to finance the introduction of foreign troops into Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Bicentennial Decision May Be Revised
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 — The executive committee of President Nixon's Bicentennial Advisory Commission will prob ably revise the first draft of its recommendations for celebrat ing the country's 200th birthday in 1976, Dr. J. E. Wallace Ster ling the commission chairman, said in a telephone interview today.
author: By Donald Janson Special to The New York Times

lead_paragraph: SST Benefits

headline: TOWNS ATACKED NEAR PNOMPENH
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 12 — North. Vietnamese and Vietcong forces were reported to have launched two more at tacks today in their continuing campaign of harassing the Cam bodian Government.
author: By Sydney H. Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: Allies Foresee an Increase In Terrorism by Vietcong
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12—The enemy's slaying of civilians in a hamlet near Danang early yesterday is being pointed out by allied officials here as clear evidence of increasing Vietcong ter rorism aimed at thwarting Saigon's gains in the country side.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: McCarthy Tours Bronx Wards, Says Veterans' Care Is Poor
lead_paragraph: Members of a Congressional committee, including Repre sentative Richard Max Mc Carthy, toured the Bronx Vet erans Administration Hospital in Kingsbridge Road yesterday and were shocked by a statement by a paralyzed veteran of the war in Vietnam that a doctor had refused to give him braces so he could attempt to walk again.
author: By Alfonso 0. Narvaez

headline: Hart, Seeking Third Term, Opposes Asia Involvement
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 12 (UPI)— Senator Philip A. Hart, Demo crat of Chicago, announced today that he was running for a third term and repeated his appeal the nation “get out of Indochina” and turn its efforts to solving the problems at home.

headline: BRENNEV SAYS U.S. SPURS AGGRESSION AS IT TALKS PEACE
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 12—Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, accused the Nixon Administration today of talking about peace while carrying out “aggressive actions that aggra vate international tensions.”
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Chilly Breeze From Moscow
lead_paragraph: Moscow's three top leaders have underscored this week the chasm that separates the two superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union. Thus Com munist party chief Brezhnev has emphasized that Soviet‐American differences “are really deep”; Presi dent Podgorny characterized relations as “in a kind of frozen state,” and Premier Kosygin attacked this country as the “main source of international tension.” To these unfriendly words, Moscow has now added an announcement that it is sending additional aid to North Vietnam.

headline: Richardson, in New job, Faces Discontent in Ranks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 12 — Employes of the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare want Elliot L. Richardson, when he becomes Secretary of the department, to convene with them the meet ing that the outgoing Secretary, Robert H. Finch, missed be cause of illness.
author: ByPaul Delaney Special to The New York Times

headline: Gadfly on the Left Needles His Peers
lead_paragraph: AREAL ESTATE man attacking profit ‐grubbing and greed among his peers? One who says that some New York commercial buildings are put up just for the buck? Who is organizing a businessman's seminar to hear William Kunstler, Allen Ginsberg and a spokesman for homosexuals? Who has sunk $10,000 Into en Off‐Broadway play that offered nudity and a preachment against the Vietnam war? And who says, “Yes, I'm on the Left.”
author: By Alden Whitman

headline: Thieu Asserts U.S. Will Not Pull Out For ‘Several’ Year
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 13 — President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam predicted today that his forces would be engaged in a long war in Cambodia and that American troops would re main in his own country for “several years more.”
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Humphrey in Senate Race; Leaves Door Ajar for '72
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, June 13— Hubert H. Humphrey announced his candidacy for the United States Senate today.
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biblical assurance that ye shall have the poor always with you has never ruffled Americans, who took it for granted that the Bible didn't mean right in your own neigh borhood. But recently the asser tion has been raised that the Constitution protects the rights of poor people to acquire living space in every community, and when the Supreme Court agreed last week to hear a case that could bolster this claim, the ac tion caused an uneasy stir.

headline: U.S. BIDS COURT SHUN ACTION IN BERK CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13 — The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court yesterday not to block the United States Army from sending to Vietnam a soldier who contends Newt York State law forbids the gov ernment to send New York, servicemen overseas to fight an unconstitutional war.

headline: Laird Said to Tighten Rein On the Joint Chiefs of Stall
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13— After 16 months of giving mili tary leaders their head at the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has reportedly decided to rein them in.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Monsoon Mud Mires U. S. Tanks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13—The war is quieter when it rains.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: FOE IN CAMBODIA ENTERS KEY TOWN ON ROUTE TO PORT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 14—Enemy troops mounted fresh attacks on the key town of Kompong Speu, about 30 miles southwest of Pnompenh, the Cambodian cap ital, and lead elements fought their way into the center of the town, a Cambodian military communiqué said today.

headline: THANT REBUFFED BY HANOI ON TALKS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 13—The North Vietnamese spokesman at the Paris talks has denounced as “sheer hypocrisy” the proposal of U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, for an expanded international confer enc on the war in Iindochina.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Several things seemed immediately apparent when Richard M. Nixon, in a swift Cabinet shuffle that caught most of the capital by surprise, moved Robert H. Finch and George P. Shultz into the White House and closer to his inner circle of advisers.

headline: U.S. WITHDRAWAL BY 71 IS BACKED
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., June 13— With United States forces scheduled to be out of Cam bodia before the end of the month, the debate over the war will almost certainly center on the rate of withdrawal of troops from Vietnam.

headline: The American as blind giant unable to see what it kills
lead_paragraph: My Lai 4
author: By Robert Jay Lipton

headline: Some Aides Doubt U.S. Can Stop Reds in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 13— The Nixon Administration is faced with what some of its high officials are privately de scribing as a perhaps impos sible task preventing a com munist takeover of Cambodia.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: In The Nation: Legislating an End to the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—The Senate's rejection, 52–47, of an attempt backed by President Nixon to water down the Church‐Cooper amendment assures Senate pas sage of that legislation, which would halt any form of Ameri can participation in the war in Cambodia after June 30. And that means one more step has been taken to restore some bal ance between Congressional au thority and that of the Com mander in Chief of the armed forces.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: TENNESSEE FREES HECKLER OF NIXON
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. June 13 —The first youth tried for heck ling President Nixon last month at a Billy Graham crusade serv ice here was freed this week because of a faulty search warrant. But arresting officers said later that they would take the case directly to the grand jury.

headline: Harvard Class of '45 Adopts Antiwar Stand
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 —The Harvard College class of 1945, gathered here this week for its 25th re union, adopted by an over whelming margin a resolution condemning the war in Vietnam.

headline: SORENSEN SCORED FOR PEACE VIEWS
lead_paragraph: The stockholdings of Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger came under political attack yes terday as the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator held their second televised debate in two days.
author: By Maurice Carroll

headline: HUMPHREY HOLDS ECONOMY IS ISSUE
lead_paragraph: WAVERLY, Minn., June 14— The nation's economy, not the war in Vietnam, will be the central issue in this fall's elec tion, former Vice President Hu bert H. Humphrey said today.
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Role in Southeast Asia

headline: Ceylon to Recognize Vietcong; Plans Steps to Become Republic
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 14 (AP)—The two‐week‐old Gov ernment of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, in a sharp swing away from the West, an nounced today that it would recognize North Vietnam, North Korea, East Germany and the Vietcong's provisional revolu tionary government of South Vietnam.

headline: Public Opinion Experts Contend Youth Has Not Opposed War as Much as Many Believe
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 14—Two stu dents of public opinion have concluded that the young and the college‐educated have not opposed the war in Vietnam as much as popularly supposed.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: 100 Buddhists in Saigon Protest at Monk's Funeral
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 (UPI)—About 100 eld erly Buddhist women and youths carrying signs reading “Americans go home” joined funeral procession today for a 74‐year‐old monk who immolat ed himself in the cause of peace. The demonstration was peaceful.

headline: Book Industry Urged to Devote Day to Peace Action
lead_paragraph: A large group of executives, editor sand authors has ap pealed to the book publishing industry across the country to devote next Wednesday to “positive action for peace” by allowing employes to hold as semblies or lobby for political candidates opposed to the In dochina war.

headline: NAVY CONDUCTING SABOTAGE INQUIRY
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 14 (AP)—A Vietnam‐bound Navy destroyer has been sidelined for two months by what the Navy suspects was sabotage. Three sailors are being held.

headline: Allies Fight to Recapture City South of Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14—Cambodian and South Vietnamese troops fought un der cover of artillery barrages and fighter‐bomber attacks to day to regain control of the Cambodian city of Kompong Speu and keep open a vital link to the sea.

headline: Nixon Losing Hope for Tax on Leaded Gas

headline: Student Protesters Denouncing Thieu Also Assail the U.S.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15—For the second time in three days, there was a de cidedly anti‐American flavor to the demonstrations staged to day by students protesting against the Thieu Government.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: 500 at Battery Honor Flag
lead_paragraph: About 500 people participated in a Battery Park ceremony yes terday observing the 193d an niversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the American flag. The spectators loudly applauded Thomas W. Gleason, president of the Inter national Longshoremen's Asso ciation, when he reiterated the continuing support of long shoremen for President Nixon's efforts to end the Vietnam war “with honor.” There were sev eral muted boos when it was announced that Mayor Lindsay had sent a telegram stating that he could not attend.

headline: Antiwar‐Bloc Educators Endorse 18 Candidates for Congress
lead_paragraph: A national antiwar coalition of college educators announced yesterday the endorsement of 18 candidates for Congress and the initial contribution of $50, 000 to their primary campaigns.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: WAR‐POWERS BILL IS FILED BY JAVITS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15— Senator Jacob K. Javits today broadened and perhaps ex tended the Senate's constitu tional debate by proposing that Congress limit by law the war making powers of the Presi dency.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: FR STILL HOLDS CAMBODIAN CITY DESPITE ATTACKS
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15—A task force of South Vietnamese and Cambodians failed in three attacks today to drive enemy troops out of Kompong Speu and to break blockade of vital supplies from Cambodia's sole deep ‐ water port.

headline: WHITE HOUSE DENIES INQUIRY ON PETITION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) —The White House said today that no investigation was under way and no dossier being com piled on some 250 State De partment employes who signed a petition opposing Nixon Ad ministration policies in Cam bodia.

headline: 17 Arrested at Pentagon During a ‘Mass for Peace’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) — Seventeen antiwar protesters were arrested today as they tried to celebrate a “mass for peace” inside the Pentagon.

headline: Cambodia Accuses Reds Of Mining Angkor Wat
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15 (UPI)— Cambodian military spokesmen said to day that the North Vietnam ese had set up a command post at the Temple of Lolei outside the Angkor complex of renowned temple ruins. The Vietnamese Communists were reported to have seized control of the area a few days ago.

headline: AGNEW TO PURSUE A ‘FEARLESS’ ROLE
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 15 — Vice President Agnew said here to night that he would continue to speak out “forcefully, factual ly and fearlessly” and would not eliminate emotion from his public appeals.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: REPRISALS PREDICTED IN VIETCONG VICTORY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) —The Pentagon made public to day a study by the Rand Cor poration speculating on the pos sible effects of a Vietcong take over in South Vietnam. The study found that reprisal kill ings could number at least 100,000 and said this figure could easily he higher.

headline: A.B.C. EASES CURB ON TV FUND PLEAS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 — Under pressure from the Demo cratic party, the American Broadcasting Company appears to have relaxed its rule against television advertising to solicit funds.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Says U.S. Troop Cuts In Asia Aid Units in Europe
lead_paragraph: GRAFENWOHR, West Ger many, June 15 (UPI)—Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that United States combat strength in Europe was increasing as it was reduced in Southeast Asia.

headline: SAIGON IMPATIENT ON THAI WAR ROLE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15—Authoritative South Vietnamese sources expressed impatience today with what they considered to be stalling by Thailand in rallying to the defense of Cambodia.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Minneapolis Rights Unit Charges Lack of Help by Police Leaves It Impotent
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, June 12—For two and a half years the Min neapolis Human Relations Com mission has been trying to handle complaints of police harassment of the city's black and Indian minorities and to punish those found guilty of it.
author: By Seth S. King Special to The New York Times

headline: Indian Party Bids Foreign Forces Quit Indochina
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, June 15—Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Con gress party has demanded the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Indochina “commencing with the Americans,” as a prel ude for a negotiated peace.

headline: INDONESIAN IS FLYING TO SOVIET FOR TALK
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15 (Reuters) — Foreign Minister Adam Malik left today by air to head an Asian peace‐seeking mission in discussions about Cambodian with Soviet leaders.

headline: ANTIWAR DEMOCRAT WINNER IN DELAWARE
lead_paragraph: DOVER, Del., June 16 (UPI)— John Daniel lo, a Newcastle County councilman who ran on an anti‐war platform, won the Democratic nomination for Con gress today in Delaware's only statewide primary election.

headline: Penalties Barred for Protesting Diplomatic Officials
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16 — The State Department has as sured Government officials who signed a letter last month to Secretary of State William P. Rogers protesting the incursion into Cambodia that no “formal or informal” punishment would he taken against them, the American Foreign Service Asso ciation said today.

headline: Priest in Massachusetts Is Opposed as Politician
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Mass, June 15— At the Massachusetts Demo cratic Convention last weekend a woman approached the Rev. Robert F. Drinan and told him she could not vote for him be cause he was a priest and be longed in a parish, not in pol itics.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine in Danang Pleads Innocent in Killing of 16
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 16 (Reuters)—A United States marine private pleaded innocent today to a charge of premeditated murder of 11 children and 5 women on Feb. 19 in a hamlet near this base city.

headline: ROLE AS A CRITIC ABJURED BY RUSK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16— Dean Rusk, the former Secre tary of State, tonight broke 18 months of silence on United States foreign policy to say that he could not “throw brick bats” at President Nixon for his failure to find peace in southeast Asia because the Ken nedy and‐Johnson Administra tions had also failed.

headline: Three Captured U.S. Reporters Are Freed in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 (AP)—Three American cor respondents, captured May 7 by Communist troops in Cam bodia, arrived in Saigon today, apparently in good condition after being freed by their cap tors.

headline: Cambodian City Retaken, But Enemy Troops Escape
lead_paragraph: KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, June 16—South Vietnamese and Cambodian infantry and armored units drove into this provincial capital and regional military headquarters today but found that the large enemy force they had hoped to trap had vanished.

headline: Hanoi Sees All Indochina as an Arena
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16— North Vietnam has announced that it will “fight shoulder to shoulder with the fraternal peoples of Laos and Cam bodia.” The pledge is being viewed here as a commitment by Hanoi to merge the hostili ties in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia into a single inte grated Indochin amilitary the ater.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Soviet and Indochina
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 16—Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indo nesia and colleagues from Japan and Malaysia flew here today and Secretary General Thant arrives tomorrow on separate but similar missions: to per suade Moscow to use its good offices to get negotiations started to end the fighting now spreading through out Indochina. But despite the burst of diplomatic ac tivity, the mood in Moscow these days is not encouraging for an early end to the bloodshed. lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 16—De fense Department sources re vealed today that there were “about 10,000” American troops still in Cambodia. The President has pledged that all United States troops will be out by June 30.

headline: APOLOGY IS ASKED BY INDUSTRIALIST

author: By Thomas P. Ronan

headline: Indiana Democrats on War
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, June 16— The Indiana Democratic State Convention adopted today a resolution urging “prompt and orderly disengagement” of American forces from South east Asia.
